analysis_text:
> DETAILS
This is a Marschak-Machina triangle. It represents all lotteries over three ordered outcomes as points inside a triangle, where the top corner corresponds to certainty of the best outcome and the right corner corresponds to certainty of the worst outcome. The position of a point reflects the probabilities assigned to these outcomes, with the probability of the remaining middle outcome determined implicitly so that all probabilities sum to one. Moving within the triangle changes probability mass across outcomes while keeping payoffs fixed, so the geometry represents probability tradeoffs rather than changes in outcomes. Indifference curves drawn over the triangle summarize preferences, with straight parallel lines characterizing expected utility and systematic curvature or fanning indicating violations of it.

he preferences in this triangle are close to straight, nearly parallel indifference curves, indicating behavior that is broadly consistent with a stable expected-utility-style tradeoff across lotteries. Relative to the risk-neutral benchmark, the implied tradeoff is slightly steeper in many regions: increasing the probability of the worst outcome generally requires more than a one-for-one increase in the probability of the best outcome to keep a lottery equally attractive. There is little evidence of strong curvature or dramatic fanning, so departures from linearity appear modest rather than structural. Overall, the pattern is best described as close to risk-neutral evaluation with a mild additional sensitivity to downside risk.
tldr_text: This decision maker is fairly close to risk-neutral, but its a bit cautious: if the chance of the bad outcome goes up, it wants a somewhat bigger increase in the chance of the good outcome to make the gamble worthwhile.
